docs.snippet: Gun rights were at the heart of many speeches by Republican presidential candidates and potential candidates at the National Rifle Association Leadership Forum here, but nearly every one used arguments for protecting the Second Amendment as a launch...
docs.abstract: Gun rights were at the heart of many speeches by Republican presidential candidates and potential candidates at the National Rifle Association Leadership Forum here, but nearly every one used arguments for protecting the Second Amendment as a launch pad to criticize President Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline.main: Candidates Trade Talk of Guns for Attacks on Clinton at N.R.A. Forum

docs.snippet: A former ambassador to South Korea says he once suggested that Kim Jong Un be invited to the United States for an "orientation trip" when Kim's father still led North Korea, but the idea was rejected — which he calls a mistake.

docs.abstract: Editorial asserts National Rifle Assn's requirement that any guns brought to its convention in Tennessee must have their firing pins removed is ultimate in hypocrisy for organization that advocates having fully functioning guns across America; questions whether Republican presidential aspirants scheduled to speak at convention will dare to run afoul of NRA by offering practical solution for reducing gun violence plaguing nation.

headline.main: No Firing Pins, Please, as the N.R.A. Gathers
headline.print_headline: No Firing Pins, Please, as the N.R.A. Gathers

docs.snippet: NATHAN--Vivian, gifted actor, mentor and teacher, died in her sleep Friday night, April 3, 2015 at The Actors Home in Englewood, NJ. She was 98 years old and an original member of The Actors Studio, founded in 1947 by Lee Strasberg, Elia Kazan,...
docs.lead_paragraph: NATHAN--Vivian, gifted actor, mentor and teacher, died in her sleep Friday night, April 3, 2015 at The Actors Home in Englewood, NJ. She was 98 years old and an original member of The Actors Studio, founded in 1947 by Lee Strasberg, Elia Kazan, Robert Lewis and Cheryl Crawford among others. Vivian made her Broadway debut after winning the John Golden Auditions and appeared in such Broadway productions as "Sundown Beach", directed by Elia Kazan, as well as the first plays by Tennessee Williams, including "The Rose Tattoo" with Maureen Stapleton and "Camino Real" with Eli Wallach, David J. Stewart and Joseph Anthony. For her portrayal of the Charwoman in "Anastasia" directed by Alan Schneider, she won the 1955 Clarence Derwent award. In "The Investigation" by Peter Weiss, a docudrama about Auschwitz, her performance was so riveting audiences believed she had been a holocaust survivor. Her last Broadway performance was in "Golda" with Anne Bancroft directed by Arthur Penn. In addition to her Broadway work that spanned from 1948 to 1977 she participated, at the Actors Studio and theaters across the country, in numerous productions by Ibsen, Chekhov and O'Neill whose plays she profoundly loved. Her 19 film appearances include "Teacher's Pet" with Clark Gable, "The Young Savages" with Burt Lancaster, and "The Outsider" with Tony Curtis. In "Klute" with Jane Fonda and Donald Sutherland, she played Jane's psychiatrist, infusing those scenes with a powerful emotional reality. She featured in over 50 television productions. Her favorite experiences were doing live television in "Playhouse 90" and "Studio One". She appeared regularly in "Alfred Hitchcock Presents" from 1958 through 1961 and worked in television until 1989. Until 1999, Vivian served on the Board of Directors for The Actors Studio with Ellen Burstyn, Estelle Parsons, Paul Newman, Lee Grant and Al Pacino. As a session moderator and teacher, Vivian's acute understanding and passion of the actor's craft brought an internal clarity to all those who worked with her. She was held in high regard by her peers. The actress, Kim Stanley, never prepared a part without working with her friend and mentor, Vivian Nathan. Born Vivian Firko in 1916 in New York City, Vivian was the daughter of Hipolit and Anna Firko. Her husband of over 50 years, Nathan Schwalb, died in 2000. She is survived by her three nieces, Diane Everline, Vivian Mullett and Elizabeth Lebens, as well as her god-daughter Elissa Myers and Ms. Myers' children, Nina and Sasha Friedman, as well as her oldest friend, Nohmie Myers. She will be greatly missed. She was greatly loved. The memorial service will be at "The Riverside," 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY on Sunday April 12 at 5:00pm. 1/3

docs.snippet: SELIGMAN--Donald David, passed away on April 6, 2015. Loving husband of 74 years to his dear wife Dorothy, who survives him, dear father to John and wife Susan, and Nancy and husband Harry Goldmark, adoring and adored grandfather and "Pop" to Ken...
docs.lead_paragraph: SELIGMAN--Donald David, passed away on April 6, 2015. Loving husband of 74 years to his dear wife Dorothy, who survives him, dear father to John and wife Susan, and Nancy and husband Harry Goldmark, adoring and adored grandfather and "Pop" to Ken (Lisa), James (Julia), Brian (Autumn) and Dori (Eric), great-grandchildren Charlotte, Lola, Nina and Alexander, and sister to Diane Tuska, who survives him. He was born July 21, 1921, and was raised by his parents in the Five Towns on Nassau County's South Shore. He was a three sports star at Lawrence High School. Don then went on to Columbia University, where he again played and lettered in three sports. Upon graduation, he enlisted in the United States Marine Corps, commissioned as Second Lieutenant, and served in the Pacific theater, including Peleliu, attaining the rank of Major before being discharged after World War II ended. He embarked upon a career in the ladies' shoe business, first at several department stores, including Lord & Taylor, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman-Delman, before opening and operating his own chain, the totally unique Shop for Pappagallo-NYC, and four other Northeast locations, for over 10 years. Don then repped for several lines of designer accessories, before retiring and moving to Rhinebeck NY, where he and Dorothy lived for almost 20 years; in a home which was a very special "go to" home base for his children and grandchildren. This was followed up by another almost two decades in Heritage Hills, Somers, NY, and the final few years in Ossining, NY at the Atria. He was a fine athlete, playing tennis well into his 80s, and a lifelong New York Rangers fan. Never has a husband, father, and grandfather given more love, guidance, and happiness to his family, extended family, friends, colleagues, and anyone else with whom he came in contact. His modesty, warmth, wit, and charm, will be missed. There will be a private funeral for immediate family on Sunday. Shiva at John and Susan Seligman's home, 45 Main Street, Hastings on Hudson, NY on Sunday from 3 to 9pm and Monday from 2pm to 4pm and 6:30pm to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to your favorite charity, in Don's memory. 1/3

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, DONALD DAVID

docs.lead_paragraph:
SELIGMAN--Donald David,

passed away on April 6, 2015. Loving husband of 74 years to his dear wife Dorothy, who survives him, dear father to John and wife Susan, and Nancy and husband Harry Goldmark, adoring and adored grandfather and "Pop" to Ken (Lisa), James (Julia), Brian (Autumn) and Dori (Eric), great-grandchildren Charlotte, Lola, Nina and Alexander, and sister to Diane Tuska, who survives him. He was born July 21, 1921, and was raised by his parents in the Five Towns on Nassau County's South Shore. He was a three sports star at Lawrence High School. Don then went on to Columbia University, where he again played and lettered in three sports. Upon graduation, he enlisted in the United States Marine Corps, commissioned as Second Lieutenant, and served in the Pacific theater, including Peleliu, attaining the rank of Major before being discharged after World War II ended. He embarked upon a career in the ladies' shoe business, first at several department stores, including Lord & Taylor, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman-Delman, before opening and operating his own chain, the totally unique Shop for Pappagallo-NYC, and four other Northeast locations, for over 10 years. Don then repped for several lines of designer accessories, before retiring and moving to Rhinebeck NY, where he and Dorothy lived for almost 20 years; in a home which was a very special "go to" home base for his children and grandchildren. This was followed up by another almost two decades in Heritage Hills, Somers, NY, and the final few years in Ossining, NY at the Atria. He was a fine athlete, playing tennis well into his 80s, and a lifelong New York Rangers fan. Never has a husband, father, and grandfather given more love, guidance, and happiness to his family, extended family, friends, colleagues, and anyone else with whom he came in contact. His modesty, warmth, wit, and charm, will be missed. There will be a private funeral for immediate family on Sunday. Shiva at John and Susan Seligman's home, 45 Main Street, Hastings on Hudson, NY on Sunday from 3 to 9pm and Monday from 2pm to 4pm and 6:30pm to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to your favorite charity, in Don's memory.
